docs.snippet: Protests over a proposed mandatory meal charge at Lafayette College, which would have added as much as $1,100 to the college's annual fees, have resulted in what many students consider to be a Pyrrhic victory. All students -- even those who do not...
docs.lead_paragraph: Protests over a proposed mandatory meal charge at Lafayette College, which would have added as much as $1,100 to the college's annual fees, have resulted in what many students consider to be a Pyrrhic victory. All students -- even those who do not use campus dining rooms -- must still buy the new meal ticket, called Flex Dollars, but none will pay more than $250 a semester for it. The added expense comes on the heels of a 9.5 percent rise in tuition, room and board that raised the total cost of attending Lafayette in the next academic year to $15,475.

headline.main: Campus Life: Lafayette; Students Win Cut In New Meal Fees But All Must Pay

docs.snippet: Knowing Your Oranges    The Florida Department of Citrus has started a campaign to educate consumers about buying juice oranges. With an abundant harvest expected for this season, about 50 percent ahead of last year's freeze-damaged crop, there wi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Knowing Your Oranges The Florida Department of Citrus has started a campaign to educate consumers about buying juice oranges. With an abundant harvest expected for this season, about 50 percent ahead of last year's freeze-damaged crop, there will be plenty of Florida oranges on the market. Florida grapefruits will also be in good supply. Freeze damage occurred this season in California, where 80 percent of the navel orange crop was destroyed by two Arctic air masses descending into the San Joaquin Valley late last month; prices for navel oranges are expected to rise dramatically. The Florida citrus department is trying to dispel the notion that a ripe orange must have orange skin. "We know based on research that the American consumer makes his or her orange purchase decisions based primarily on color," said Dr. Dan L. Gunter, the department's executive director. No oranges are picked before they are mature, regardless of whether the skin is bright orange or completely green. Cooler nighttime temperatures are needed to set the orange color; oranges from areas where the nights are warm tend to retain some green in the skin. The same is true of grapefruits that may appear more greenish than yellowish. They're from warmer regions of the state. As for artificially colored oranges, Dr. Gunter said they account for about 10 percent of those sold retail. "We only color them when a broker or a retailer requests it," he said. "One object of this campaign is to be able to eliminate the practice." He also said the bumper crop had brought orange juice prices down to an average of $4.04 a gallon as of December, from a high last year of $4.59. "Retail prices should continue to fall if stores pass along the benefits of the wholesale reductions to consumers," he said. A Buffet of Comfort Foods Providing comfort while buying and eating "comfort foods" is the object of a benefit at Miss Ruby's Cafe, 135 Eighth Avenue (16th Street), at 7 P.M. Jan. 24. The benefit, for the Children's AIDS Network, involves a buffet dinner of meat loaf, casseroles, mashed potatoes, homemade pies and the like, followed by an auction, at 8:30, of many similar dishes to take home to freeze or to eat over the weekend. The price of tickets, including beer and wine, is $60 a person. For reservations: (212) 620-4055. The Whys of Cooking A couple of interesting books have recently been published for those who would like to know the whys of cooking, not just the hows. "The Curious Cook" by Harold McGee ( North Point Press , $19.95), is every bit as scientific as Mr. McGee's previous book, "On Food and Cooking" (Scribners, 1984), but is less weighty and more personal than the first book. The new book is a collection of essays and lively reflections on cooking matters and questions like preventing salads from turning brown or whether searing meat really seals in the juices. Mr. McGee is endowed with healthy skepticism and loves to take a generally accepted cooking practice (like searing meat), test it according to every variable and come up with contradictory results. He speculates on how the theory came about and sweeps the reader along the logical progress of his thinking and his own enthusiasm for discovery. The book is hard to put down. He has done a great job on mayonnaise, taking apart the notion that an egg yolk can absorb no more than three-quarters of a cup of oil and, while he's at it, coming up with a recipe using safe, cooked yolks. Other useful confusions , like why it's all right to rinse mushrooms clean instead of wiping them, as many books advise, and why opening the oven for a minute or so will not damage whatever is baking, are based on scientific evidence. "The Epicurean Laboratory" by Tina Seelig ( William Freeman & Company, $15.95) answers many of the typical questions like why bread rises or souffles fall and would serve as a basic primer for students of cooking. But there is no investigation of generally accepted cooking notions, some of which Mr. McGee debunks, like the assumption that cold liquids freeze much faster than hot liquids. Peanut Butter (Cont.) No longer is the choice simply smooth or chunky. There's more. Peanut Butter Classics in Pawling, N.Y., offers cinnamon raisin -- sensational on a good raisin nut bread -- and chocolate chip flavors. These come in both smooth or chunky versions in 12-ounce jars. A package of all four is $30 including shipping. For information: (914) 855-3050. These flavored peanut butters are sold individually by a number of stores, among them the Burke & Burke stores in Manhattan, where they are $7.99 each; Bloomingdale's, White Plains, $7; Ronna's Sweet Necessities, 1 Chase Road, Scarsdale, N.Y., $5.25; Sigmund's, 683 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, L.I., $4.99; and From Fruits to Nuts, 508 Milbourn Avenue, Short Hills, N.J., $7.20. Another seductive peanut butter variation is peanut honey butter, a velvety whipped blend of peanuts and honey from Oregon Apiaries in Newberg, Ore. A 12-ounce jar is $5 at Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (74th Street). The Art of Blind Tasting This semester, Harriet Lembeck has added an intriguing course to her wine and spirits program in mid-Manhattan. Called "The Techniques of Blind Tasting," it explains how to evaluate wines in a blind tasting, showing the role of different components and the differences in various grapes, vinifying methods and aging. It will be conducted in two sessions, Feb. 12 and 19, 7:30 to 9:30 P.M. at the Helmsley Hotel, 212 East 42d Street. The course is open only to those who have completed Ms. Lembeck's regular eight-session course and to professionals in wine. The cost is $180. For information and registration: (718) 263-3134. In '90, More of Everything MORE new grocery and drugstore products were introduced in 1990 than in any other year since a market research company began keeping records in 1970, the company says. The concern, Marketing Intelligence Services of Naples, N.Y., said in a recent report that 15,879 new products were introduced in 1990, an increase of 18.9 percent over 1989. The previous record was set in 1987. The total surprised researchers, who, on the basis of the first quarter of 1990, had predicted a continuation of the 1988 and '89 decline in new products. In the tally of new products the company includes different sizes and flavors or varieties of existing products. These accounted for nearly two-thirds of the list. The report stressed a proliferation of products for which environmental claims were made, 11.4 percent of the total. Assertions about nutrition also played a major role, with 15 percent of new foods advertised as having low or no cholesterol and 13 percent trumpeting low fat or no fat.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE subway stalled twice on the way uptown so I was late meeting my friend at the theater. That meant we had to sit in the second row, which is perhaps not the best place to be at a film that opens with a knifing followed by a shooting. Of the same person, I might add.

docs.snippet: STEW LEONARD'S, the Disneyesque supermarket featuring dancing cows and singing milk cartons, will open its first store in Westchester as part of a new retail development now rising on a site near Austin Avenue off the New York State Thruway.    It...
docs.abstract: Stew Leonard's supermarket will open its first store outside Connecticut in Yonkers, NY; will offer audio/animation robots and costumed characters who roam aisles welcoming customers; will also have petting zoo, on-site juice processing plant and Western-themed restaurant; map; drawing; photo (In the Region/Westchester) (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: STEW LEONARD'S, the Disneyesque supermarket featuring dancing cows and singing milk cartons, will open its first store in Westchester as part of a new retail development now rising on a site near Austin Avenue off the New York State Thruway. It will be the first Stew Leonard's outside of Connecticut, where there are now two stores, one in Danbury and another in Norwalk. ''People from Westchester have been asking us if we were ever going to open a store there,'' said Stew Leonard Jr., the company president. ''They travel to our stores in Connecticut so we know we already have a built-in customer base in the county.''

headline.main: In the Region/Westchester; Stew Leonard's Taking Its Dancing Cows to Yonkers

docs.snippet: The South Korean Red Cross plans to begin shipping 15,000 tons of corn to North Korea next week to help stave off famine, the secretary general of the organization said today.     Lee Byung Woong said his organization also planned to give its Nort...
docs.abstract: South Korean Red Cross will begin shipping 15,000 thousand tons of food to North Korea to help stave off famine (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The South Korean Red Cross plans to begin shipping 15,000 tons of corn to North Korea next week to help stave off famine, the secretary general of the organization said today. Lee Byung Woong said his organization also planned to give its North Korean counterpart an estimate of how much other food aid was planned. That issue had created a deadlock in talks aimed at speeding up the shipment of aid.

headline.main: South Korean Red Cross To Ship Food Aid to North

docs.snippet: LONG Island ducks and potatoes are known far beyond our borders. So too are the tiny scallops harvested in Peconic Bay. Add the Island's fish, oysters, clams, cauliflower, corn, tomatoes, broccoli, pumpkins, squash and increasingly well regarded p...
docs.abstract: Long Island's local produce, poultry, game and wine will be spotlighted in events sponsored by Long Island Food Experience and American Institute of Food and Wine (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: LONG Island ducks and potatoes are known far beyond our borders. So too are the tiny scallops harvested in Peconic Bay. Add the Island's fish, oysters, clams, cauliflower, corn, tomatoes, broccoli, pumpkins, squash and increasingly well regarded premium wines, and it becomes apparent that there are enough world-class local ingredients to satisfy the most demanding of chefs. A little over a year ago, two such chefs, Michael Meehan of Tupelo Honey in Sea Cliff and Tom Schaudel of 107 Forest in Locust Valley, were discussing Long Island's bountiful seafood, fruits, vegetables, game and wine as they flew home from a showcase dinner presented by the Great Chefs of Miami. They spoke of the increasing sophistication of the restaurants of Nassau and Suffolk, of the large pool of talented local chefs and they soon realized that if Miami, an area without wineries, could stage such a showcase, so could Long Island.

headline.main: A Showcase for Local Chefs and Local Bounty

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND WINE

docs.snippet: NO one in New York ever gets full.         "I'll never eat again," they moan, when the absolute last crumb disappears. But where do you find them the very next morning? Lining up for lox. You happen  to know that, of course, because, by the strang...
docs.lead_paragraph: NO one in New York ever gets full. "I'll never eat again," they moan, when the absolute last crumb disappears. But where do you find them the very next morning? Lining up for lox. You happen to know that, of course, because, by the strangest coincidence, you're there, too. Right behind them.

docs.snippet: A Chocolate Hanukkah    Hanukkah begins at sundown on Sunday, and here's a treat for each of the holiday's eight nights -- and then some. Perugina Classic chocolate bars are kosher and range from dark to milk to white chocolate. They come in 16 va...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Chocolate Hanukkah Hanukkah begins at sundown on Sunday, and here's a treat for each of the holiday's eight nights -- and then some. Perugina Classic chocolate bars are kosher and range from dark to milk to white chocolate. They come in 16 varieties, including dark chocolate with hazelnuts, milk chocolate with cappuccino filling, milk chocolate with peanut truffle filling, and white chocolate with macadamia nuts. The complete line is sold at the Perugina shop, 520 Madison Avenue (near 54th Street), for $1.85 a bar. Fancy-food shops and candy counters around the country carry a selection of the flavors. Nothing but Doughnuts Mark Isreal, formerly the manager of Angelica Kitchen, in the East Village, has opened the Doughnut Plant, a tiny wholesale bakery on the Lower East Side. There, he is putting his grandfather's doughnut recipe to good use. "He had a bakery in Greensboro, and his doughnuts were the best," said Mr. Isreal, a native of Greensboro, N.C. For the last two months, Mr. Isreal has been exhibiting familial flair for big old-fashioned glazed doughnuts that are not only delicious but also contain superior ingredients.
